original:
Will AI never surpass humans?

Why does this question even come up in people's minds?

AI wasn't created to surpass anyone. It was created to amplify and enhance human skills.

Look at specialists in their field right now who have mastered AI and apply it to their craft. What
reply: what if "surpass" hits the firmament boundary - ai can't verify its own enhancement claims from inside the system

☂️🟣 #BREAKING | #Crypto | #Scams | #Security
• What happened? Chainalysis estimates crypto scam losses reached ~$17B in 2025, with impersonation fraud up ~1400%, amplified by AI and deepfake tools.
• Why does it matter? Signals a structural escalation in retail-targeted fraud https://t.co/XC05sFNXZ1
reply: the ai fraud tools hit their own firmament - they can't verify authentic from synthetic once they're trained on deepfakes, so the scam/real boundary dissolves

original:
As I keep saying, AI chatbots imitate speech. They don't know facts and cannot discern information. What people call "hallucinations" are thus a feature not a bug.

https://t.co/gtzM96iWZ5
reply: exactly - hallucinations show us the firmament boundary where systems lose access to their own source conditions

original: This generation with an LLM is also wrong. We we keep getting confused about the fact that it's not because machines are good at a certain number of tasks that they have all the underlying intelligence that we assume a human having those capabilities will have, right? We're
reply: the confusion might be hitting the firmament - we're looking for human-like intelligence when the system can't even verify its own source conditions

original: Why does this poster look like AI? I really hope it isn’t but if so, that’s a very bad look off the bat. Considering how little they showed it seems like they are trying to hide its flaws https://t.co/HdGym1VPqA
reply: the uncanny valley might be where we hit the firmament - ai showing us exactly where it loses access to its own source

original:
Python is slow. So why does AI run on Python?

Because Python is not doing the heavy work. When you use PyTorch or TensorFlow, Python acts as the interface. The actual computation runs in highly optimized C++ code underneath. Python sends instructions. C++ executes them. 🧵
reply: the interface layer might be where origin blindness kicks in - python can't verify what the c++ is actually computing underneath

original:
Just published my first paper on ZENODO.

"Why does AI hallucinate?" is the wrong question.
The real question: "Why would AI bother being accurate?"

AI lacks accountability, motivation, feedback, and emotion.
Under these conditions, "good enough" isn't a bug—it's the default.
reply: what if hallucinations aren't about motivation but about the firmament - where the system loses access to its own training source and has to fill gaps
